awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Constraint in Marriage Systems and Fitness Outcomes
awd_abstract_narration:
Whom one selects as a partner has enormous consequences on access to resources, social support, health, and well-being. Theories abound explaining which traits are suspected to be the most desirable, yet limited research explores the consequences of constrained decision-making on whom one selects as a reproductive partner. This is despite the fact that partner choice is constrained in numerous contexts. This study seeks to understand the effects of constrained decision-making on partner choice and associated effects on health and well-being. The work will train a graduate student in scientific cultural anthropology and will provide insights relevant to debates about the causes and consequences of variation in human reproductive systems.  

A review of marriage systems indicates that the marrying individuals generally prefer different partners than those selected from within endogamous social networks. The effects of this discordance are not well studied, however. This study will be conducted in a community where roughly half of marriages involve constrained partner choice and half involve marriages in which partners are freely chosen. The research leverages this comparison to ask several important questions about the consequences of constrained reproduction. In particular, the researchers investigate whether more or healthier children result from in constrained versus unconstrained marriage. To understand these relationships, this study will measure marriage satisfaction, birth rates, child survival and growth rates, and child health, as well as material parental contributions in both types of marriages, with the ultimate goal of understanding what benefits unconstrained partner choice might provide. These findings are increasingly relevant to public health issues, especially as scientists struggle to understand the role of other processes that compromise partner-choice mechanisms, including other forms of medically assisted reproduction.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Research Questions

Many people have strong opinions about the kind of person they want to mate with or marry, and we spend a lot of time evaluating potential partners for these qualities. These time-consuming tasks likely have an evolutionary function—they steer us toward mates that have qualities that will increase our reproductive success. While this assumption has been experimentally tested in animals, the same experimental methods are not possible in humans. Instead, we have to rely on existing cultural systems where there is variation in the amount of independent mate choice individuals exercise. One such case is arranged marriages, a common system across cultures in which parents are deeply involved in choosing a partner for their offspring, sometimes with little input from the marrying individuals. Evidence indicates that parents arranging a marriage are not evaluating sons- or daughters-in-law based on the same qualities that offspring would use to find a match on their own. Therefore, individuals in arranged marriages, who are not fully expressing their mate preferences, should have reduced reproductive success, but our previous work examining this prediction does not find any differences between couples in arranged and non-arranged marriages. This project explores the reasons behind these results.

 

Study Site

We collected data from over 1,000 individuals in Dhading, Nepal, an area rapidly transitioning from a traditional system of parentally arranged marriages to self-chosen marriages with less parental involvement. In Nepal, we hired a team of local research assistants who received training on data collection and management. Some of these local researchers used that experience to secure jobs or admission to educational programs.

 

Measuring Preferences in a Marriage Partner

To investigate why previous studies of arranged and non-arranged marriages have similar reproductive outcomes, we first examined divergence between the in-law/partner preferences of parents and offspring in Dhading, Nepal. Over 700 participants allocated a budget to a set of 14 traits to design their ideal spouse (for unmarried respondents) or in-law (for parents of unmarried adults). By comparing the budget allocated to each trait by parents and unmarried individuals, we quantified the overall amount of disagreement and identified the traits causing that disagreement. We measured substantial disagreement between parents and offspring, and this disagreement was most pronounced in traits like physical attractiveness (preferred by offspring) and caste identity (preferred by parents). This portion of the project provided training for one undergraduate at UC Santa Barbara, who gained valuable data skills and coding experience in R Statistical Software.

 

Cultural Context of Arranged Marriage

We then examined the cultural context of arranged marriages in Nepal via 17 focus groups. First, these focus groups demonstrated that there are three categories of marriage in the local community—arranged marriages, love marriages, and elopements—each of which encompass varying levels of parent and offspring involvement. Second, we found a strong desire from parents and offspring to work together on selecting a spouse in an arranged marriage. Even though the budget allocation task (above) highlighted disagreement, these focus groups showed room for compromise and collaboration. Lastly, these focus groups identified several social and financial incentives tied to arranged marriages that make these an attractive option for many individuals. For example, arranged marriages provide more family support in cases of marital conflict, and arranged marriages come with substantial marital gifts. These benefits were larger for women than for men, indicating that women in this community may have substantial incentives to enter arranged marriages. For this project, we worked with two undergraduate researchers at UC Santa Barbara who coded and analyzed the focus group transcripts. These undergraduates, plus a local Nepali researcher, are coauthors on the publication.

 

Importance

These results highlight the role of kin and social support in human mating, and may explain why previous studies examining the relationship between mate choice and reproductive outcomes did not find the predicted results. This role of kin and social networks in mate choice may be unique among animals.

 

Remaining Projects

This grant supported two additional research objectives for which data was collected in Nepal during the grant period. These data have been prepared for analysis and will be analyzed in the next year. We will examine whether reproductive outcomes differ for individuals in different types of marriages (our initial hypothesis) using a more dynamic measure of spouse choice. Second, we will explore the reasons for any reproductive differences (or lack thereof) by analyzing data on grandparental support, marital gift giving, inheritances, and perceived social support to examine the costs and benefits of parental involvement in marriage decisions. During collection of these data, which included child height, weight, and body fat measurements, participants received reports of their health data to assist them in making healthcare decisions. Summative results of these analyses will also be shared with the local health clinic to help target child health programs in the communities.
